abstracts.cdata!:
The Pension and Financial Market Reform
            Technical Assistance Credit for Nicaragua had the following
            ratings: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: When
            political risks are high, project design should be much less
            ambitious with respect to policy reform commitments. Short
            and medium-run costs of reforms may be unacceptable despite
            potential long-term benefits. Lack of Borrower ownership
            will delay project implementation and undermine outcomes.
            Project design should not be too ambitious but based on
            capacity on the ground. Project appraisal should include an
            in depth analysis of financial and political risks. Public
            information campaigns should follow, not precede, the
            implementation of a reform and should focus on the reasons
            for the reforms, and present realistic expectations of their
            benefits. Having the right project coordination agency will
            result in a better implementation experience.
